If and when the Islamic State is defeated, what lies beyond is a very interesting question.

Iraq is a failed state; government authority is weak, corruption is rampant, and sectarian tribalism affects every level of society, from Parliament to the army to the streets of Baghdad. Syria is split between the diverse urban centers governed by a brutal dictator and the rural Sunni heartland with an economy and infrastructure in ruins. Power vacuums abound, and something has to fill them in the long run. From the 15th to the 19th centuries, Ottoman sultans and Persian shahs vied with one another for influence and power in the Middle East while struggling to maintain a mutually acceptable status quo and defend against European encroachment. Some similar Great Game may be developing now between Iran and Turkey, with important roles played by the Saudis, Egypt, and non-state actors like the Muslim Brotherhood and wealthy Gulf Arabs. One thing you can say about the Middle East: it's never dull.

Camp may not be for absolutely everyone, but it is beneficial and beloved by so many camp enthusiasts and converted critics, too.  There are so many lifetime   gains from experiencing sleepaway camp.  Each summer 20,000 kids head to overnight camps in Maine where over 500,000 alum have gotten to unplug, connect with nature, make new friends, have fun, learn new skills, gain confidence and independence, and so much more.  As someone who has experienced different camps and tours as a kid/teen and is now as a mom of campers, as well as the Maine Camp Experience Campcierge who helps families choose which camp is right for them, it really is important to research and find the right camp.  Everything from the culture of the camp, to the activities offered and type of programming (elective or structured), to session length, level of rusticity, and so much more can contribute to the success of a child's experience at camp.  And, I definitely think that less/moderate contact works best (i.e., in a 7-week session … a couple phone calls, a Visiting Day, and some good old fashioned letter writing).
